facts.text: Sajjan Singh joined Punjab Government service in January 1922 as Overseer in Irrigation Department, continued till July 1944, then became Sub-divisional Officer till May 1947 in area now in West Pakistan.
From November 30, 1947 to September 26, 1952, employed as Sub-Divisional Officer of Drauli Sub-Division, Nangal Circle, except short leave break.
Excavation work for Nangal Project in Drauli Sub-Division by contractors including Ramdas Chhankanda Ram and M/s. Ramdas Jagdish Ram.

On December 7, 1952, General Manager, Bhakra Dam, complained to Superintendent of Police, Hoshiarpur, alleging Sajjan Singh and subordinates obtained illegal gratification from contractors by withholding payments and obstacles.
Case registered under s.5(2) Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947; sanction obtained for prosecution under s.5(2) PCA and s.161/165 IPC.
Tried by Special Judge, Ambala, convicted under s.5(2) PCA, sentenced to 1 year RI and Rs.5000 fine (6 months RI in default).
Punjab High Court confirmed conviction and sentence in Criminal Appeal No. 683 of 1957, rejected State's enhancement application.

Prosecution case: Appellant demanded commission from Ram Das of firm Ramdas Chhankanda Ram after initial payments; first payment March 21, 1949; total Rs.10,500 cash commission, Rs.2,000 for Executive Engineer, Rs.241/12/- small sums; entered in books as Jhalu Singh Jamadar or Sajjan Singh name; fictitious credits.
Alleged payment Rs.1,800 by M/s. Ram Das Jagdish Ram, not proved.
Prosecution relied on testimony of three partners, entries in firm books, disproportionate assets: total assets Rs.1,47,502/12/- vs emoluments Rs.80,000/- on Dec 7, 1952.
Defence: Assets of wife Daya Kaur and son Bhupinder Singh not on his behalf; his own <Rs.50,000, not disproportionate; partners gave false evidence, books fictitious.

Special Judge held books relevant u/s 34 Evidence Act; accomplice evidence needs corroboration, books not independent but interspersed admitted payments provide it; assets disproportionate, presumption u/s 5(3) PCA attracted.

High Court judges differed on pre-1947 assets u/s 5(3); Harbans Singh excluded, post-1948 assets ~Rs.20,000 not disproportionate; Capoor included, disproportionate even post-April 1947-June 1950; both agreed on corroboration via interspersed entries.

Bhupinder Singh (son) assets on Dec 7, 1952: Rs.28,998/7/3 PNB, Rs.20,000 fixed deposit Bank of Patiala, Rs.5,577 Imperial Bank Moga, Rs.237/8/3 Savings Bank Patiala, half share land Ludhiana Rs.11,000.
Bhupinder's defence: Rs.20,200 from Udhe Singh Dec 1945, Rs.6,000 grandfather; disbelieved by courts.
Total salary ~Rs.80,000; TA estimates Rs.10,000 max savings; interest ~Rs.10,000; total known income ~Rs.1,03,000; expenses min Rs.36,000; net Rs.67,000 vs assets >Rs.1,20,000.

legal_issues.text: Whether pecuniary resources or property acquired before Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947 (March 11, 1947) can be considered for presumption under s.5(3) PCA.
Whether account books were kept regularly in course of business and relevant u/s 34 Evidence Act, and whether interspersed admitted entries provide independent corroboration for accomplice testimony.
Whether presumption u/s 5(3) PCA arises even if prosecution adduced other evidence.
Whether assets held by wife and son were on behalf of appellant and disproportionate to known sources of income.

petitioner_arguments.text: Books not kept regularly, entries not relevant u/s 34 Evidence Act; even if relevant, not independent corroboration, interspersed admitted entries insufficient.
Presumption u/s 5(3) PCA only for post-Act acquisitions; including pre-Act gives retrospective effect.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.5(3) Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947; Art.20 Constitution

petitioner_arguments.text: Presumption only if no other evidence adduced by prosecution; alternative mode.
Assets of wife/son not on his behalf; total <Rs.50,000 not disproportionate; other receipts from Kabul Singh, Teja Singh, father.

respondent_arguments.text: Payments of commission proved by partners' testimony, corroborated by books with interspersed admitted payments; disproportionate assets.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.5(3) Prevention of Corruption Act; s.34 Evidence Act

court_reasoning.text: s.5(3) PCA is rule of evidence, not new offence; presumption mandatory if disproportionate assets proved and not explained; includes pre-Act assets, no retrospective operation as requisites from antecedent time ok.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Pecuniary resources/property in possession on complaint date, whether pre or post Act, to be considered; no words 'acquired after Act' to add.

court_reasoning.text: Books relevant; accomplice needs corroboration, books alone not but interspersed proved payments provide it.
Presumption arises even with other evidence; not limited to no evidence cases; foreign cases distinguished.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No 'absence of evidence' words in s.5(3); burden shifts once facts proved.

court_reasoning.text: Son's assets held on behalf of father; disbelieved explanations; total assets >Rs.1,20,000 vs net known income Rs.67,000 highly disproportionate; no satisfactory account.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Known sources to prosecution; liberal TA estimate; min expenses Rs.36,000.

holdings.text: Pecuniary resources/property acquired before Act considered for s.5(3) presumption if in possession on relevant date.
Presumption under s.5(3) arises on proof of disproportionate assets unexplained; shifts burden to accused; valid even with other evidence; supports conviction under charged offence.
Disproportionate assets proved, presumption attracted, appellant failed to rebut.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Maharashtra v. Vishnu Ramchandra
precedents_cited.relevance: Statute not retrospective if part requisites from antecedent time.
s.5(3) is rule of evidence, not new offence; known sources mean to prosecution.

precedents_cited.case_name: Surajpal Singh v. State of U.P.
precedents_cited.relevance: s.5(3) presumption for charged offence only; distinguished appellant's misuse argument.
US presumption only absent substantial evidence; unlike s.5(3).

precedents_cited.case_name: Bratty v. Attorney General for Northern Ireland
precedents_cited.relevance: Presumption takes place of evidence, but does not bar prosecution evidence.

statutes_cited.name: Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines criminal misconduct; presumption from disproportionate assets shifts burden.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Prosecution sanctioned under these with PCA.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Evidence Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Entries in books relevant if regularly kept.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: No ex post facto law violation as s.5(3) not new offence.

outcome.summary: Appeal against conviction and sentence under s.5(2) PCA dismissed; presumption under s.5(3) held attracted based on disproportionate assets including pre-Act; no interference with sentence.

key_quotes.text: "In any trial of an offence punishable under sub-section (2) the fact that the accused person or any other person on his behalf is in possession, for which the accused person cannot satisfactorily account, of pecuniary resources or property disproportionate to his known sources of income may be proved, and on such proof the court shall presume, unless the contrary is proved, that the accused person is guilty of criminal misconduct..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes s.5(3) PCA central to holding.

key_quotes.text: "A statute cannot be said to be retrospective because a part of the requisites for its action is drawn from a time antecedent to its passing."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key reasoning on including pre-Act assets.

key_quotes.text: "The assets of Rs.1,20,000/- have therefore to be compared with a net income of Rs.67,000/-. They are clearly disproportionate--indeed highly disproportionate."
key_quotes.speaker: court
